snippet: The European Central Bank signaled the worst may be over for the euro zone. But the Bank of England said it would increase its purchases of government bonds to bolster the economy.
abstract: European Central Bank leaves its main interest rate unchanged, signaling the worst may be over for the euro zone; policy makers wait to see whether signs of improving growth will lead to a recovery; the Bank of England also leaves its benchmark rate unchanged, but decides to expand its asset-buying program to help the British economy avoid falling back into a recession.

byline.original: By JACK EWING and JULIA WERDIGIER
byline.contributor: Jack Ewing reported from Frankfurt and Julia Werdigier from London.

lead_paragraph: The European Central Bank signaled the worst may be over for the euro zone. But the Bank of England said it would increase its purchases of government bonds to bolster the economy.

headline.main: Central Banks in Europe Hold Line on Rates
headline.print_headline: Central Banks in Europe Hold Line on Rates
